discussion_comments.comment_body: is the whitespace here intended?
Yes. `new` is a keyword, so the space helps distinguish it from a method.
Okay, I just wanted to make sure that it wasn't a mistake.

discussion_comments.comment_body:
Would it be possible to also change this case where the multiline operators are nested? When I encounter such a case in my code, I usually refactor it so that prettier doesn't make it ugly like that. If I was writing it manually I would write something like:

```JS
  (
    isAnyValueSelected
    && node.getAttribute(radioAttr.toLowerCase()) === radioValue
  )
  || (
    !isAnyValueSelected 
    && values[a].default === true
  )
  || a === 0;
```

discussion_comments.comment_body: I'm trying to keep this change as small as possible to improve the odds the team decides to merge it. Based on the volume of :+1:s on #3806, putting binary operators at the beginning of lines has pretty widespread support. It helps that [the logic change](https://github.com/prettier/prettier/pull/7111/files#diff-3abca41914b4b214a2507e33cc54c28bL5725-R5729) to do that exclusively deletes code. I'm concerned that expanding the scope could reduce the chance it gets merged at all.

discussion_comments.comment_body: Sure. I didn't mean this comment to show as a "review" of this PR. It was just a random question :sweat_smile: This needs a separate issue.

@fisker check out 039802c03 – I went with `experimentalOperatorPosition: "start" | "end"` since that's the less verbose version. Despite the ESLint rule precedent, I personally find it easier to think about where to place the operator rather than the linebreak relative to the operator. If you all have a strong preference for some other form, I'm happy to tweak it.
I'm fine with current name.
would be awesome to get this merged!

discussion_comments.comment_body:
That was a previous PR, which is nicer in some cases but leaves a lot of problems unsolved. You can read through some of the discussion to see why.

Yes, like I mention in the PR description, this will rub some people (probably most people) the wrong way at first 😄 I recommend you try it on a codebase you work on regularly for a few days before leaping to a conclusion… is that something you could try?

discussion_comments.comment_body: This will almost certainly make things worse. There's obvious disagreement about how to do ternaries but people seemed much more okay with the old way of doing ternaries than the new way. Adding yet another third that has not received any sort of public support seems very risky. The options that have received the most support are [here](https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/5814#issuecomment-468978755) and [here](https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/9561#issuecomment-751684197) which are both very similar to the old way of doing it. Can we just go with one of those?

discussion_comments.comment_body: This PR definitely does need a thorough justification for why I think this nonstandard, unfamiliar thing is best. I've been wanting to write up that justification for a year or so and haven't found the time. I should be able to soon, and I'd really appreciate help from the other prettier maintainers (or someone in the community who wants to see ternaries get better and has an open mind) in making it happen.
